title: Davidson Posts
name: Davidson Posts
description: Davidson posts from Digital Field Scholarship, fall 2012.

properties.title: Picture with the class!
properties.author: ali defrancesch

properties.title: Making Change
properties.content: Counting/Adding by Grouping Purchase one item from the cafe using a $5.00 bill. Count your change. Did the cashier give you the least amount of coins possible? If not, what could she have done differently? How much money did you spend? How much change did you receive?

properties.title: C. Shaw Smith 900 Room Stairs
properties.content: Shapes What shape do these stairs resemble? What else can you think of that resembles this shape?

properties.title: Upper Stairs
properties.content: Adding by Grouping Note how many stairs are in each group of stairs. How many are in each group? How many stairs are there in total? Was it easier to count the stairs in groups or individually?

properties.title: Main Stairs
properties.content: Adding by Grouping Note how many stairs are in each group of stairs. How many are in each group? How many stairs are there in total? Was it easier to count the stairs in groups or individually? Â

properties.title: Track
properties.content: Shapes Find the Richardson Stadium Track (Hint the inside of it is a football field) Notice the shape of the track. How is it different from the shape of the first destination?

properties.title: Swing
properties.content: Shapes Find the swing that's located between the library, Duke dormitory hall, the Alvarez College Union and Richardson Stadium. Notice the shape of the area surrounding the swing. What is it? What are the characteristics of this shape?

properties.title: Reflection 4
properties.author: Hilary Zipperstein
properties.content: On Monday, after a long night of wondering how to make this project more accessible, Collin and I went out to geotag some completely new sites. I had emailed Henry Neale to go over our new plans and this afternoon, Collin and Amanda will be discussing the improvements with him. Hopefully, we can present our project tomorrow, and have all the kinks worked out by Friday.

properties.title: Problem 7
properties.author: Kenneth Henson
properties.content: Gazebos and Geometry There is a gazebo not far from the map. Go stand inside the gazebo and look at the shape of the ground. The gazebo is the shape of an octagon, so how many sides does it have? If each side is 1 meter long, then three sides added together make up what fraction of the total perimeter?

properties.title: Problem 6
properties.author: Kenneth Henson
properties.content: A Piece of Lake NormanAt this point along the path there is a map of Lake Norman near the shore. A star on the map indicates where you are standing. From this location you should be able to see the entire bay (weâll call it Little Lake Davidson), which is cut off from the rest of the lake by I-77 (the highway). Â The total perimeter of Lake Normanâs coastline is about 500 miles long. Given that the length of the highway that splits the bay is about one mile long, estimate the perimeter of the coastline. Now consider that Little Lake Davidsonâs coastline makes up slightly less than two hundreths of the total coastline and change your estimate if needed.

properties.title: Problem 5
properties.author: Kenneth Henson
properties.content: Dividing the BayAt the Canoe Launch site there is a bench that looks across the lakeâs bay. Seated from this bench, if you look straight across you notice a dock about three fifths of the total distance across. If it is 500 yards from the bench to the other side, how far away is the dock?

properties.title: Problem 4
properties.author: Kenneth Henson
properties.content: Canoe Racks and FractionsThere are more canoe racks at the Canoe Launch site. But, if you stand and face one of these racks, you can see that two horizontal boards cut the vertical board instead of just one. These racks can hold up to six canoes. Examine one rack: what fraction of the spots have canoes in them? Now look at two racks together: how many canoes would there be if three fourths of the spots were being filled? Of these canoes, if five are green, what fraction of the canoes are not green?

properties.title: Problem 3
properties.author: Kenneth Henson
properties.content: Splitting CrossesThe canoe racks are made of two wooden crosses. Each cross is the exact same size and is constructed using two wooden boards, one vertical and one horizontal. Stand and face one of the crosses. The vertical board 6 feet tall and the horizontal boards two thirds of the way up. Â How far away from the ground is the horizontal board?

properties.title: Problem 2
properties.author: Kenneth Henson
properties.content: Holes in the Fence The path to the trail is fenced on both sides. The fence is cut into large rectangles, with each rectangle separated by black metal poles. If you look at one rectangular, you can see how it is made up of black wires that form many diamond-shaped holes. How many diamond-shaped holes do you think there are in each rectangle? How did you come up with this guess?

properties.title: Problem 1
properties.author: Kenneth Henson
properties.content: Welcome SignAt the street entrance of the trail behind Davidson Day School is a square sign made of four wooden planks. Another wooden plank splits the square in half into two rectangles of equal area. With measuring tape, measure the length (in feet) of each plank. Using these measurements, what is the total area of the square? What is the total area of one rectangle?

properties.title: Converting Distance
properties.author: Matt Zarth
properties.content: The distance between the boat racks and the Gazebo is 207 yds.How many feet is this if there are three feet in a yard?Now estimate the number of strides that it takes for you to get from the boat racks to the Gazebo.If each stride is a yard how close were you to 207 yds?Printable Worksheet.Answer Key.

properties.title: The Pit
properties.author: Matt Zarth
properties.content: The Pit is 27 ft 7.5in by 20 ft 2 in by 3 ft 10.5 in. Convert these numbers into inches. Using the converted numbers find the volume in inches cubed. How many 2 in by 2 in by 2 in or 2 cubic inch boxes could fit into the pit? Printable worksheet. Answer Key.

properties.title: Fuel Pizza Dilemma
properties.author: Rachel Cole
properties.content: You go to Fuel Pizza with your family and are trying to decide whether or not to order a whole pizza or have each family member get his or her own slices of pizza. Whatâs a better deal - a Fuel whole pizza (8 slices) for $11.97 or 8 slices for $1.54 each?

properties.title: Recess Time Splits
properties.author: Rachel Cole
properties.content:
Let's head to recess! If you have 20 minutes to play on the playground but want to have time on four structures (the slide, the swings, the monkey bars, and the tire swing), how can you divide your time evenly?

What if you want to spend extra time on one structure, like the tire swing, more than the other three structures? How can you divide your time then?

properties.title: Acute, Obtuse, and Right...Oh My!
properties.author: Rachel Cole
properties.content:
Look at the angles of the playground equipment, specifically the tire swing â is this angle acute, obtuse, or right?

Then see if you can find other acute, obtuse, and right angles on the playground!

properties.title: Ticking Time at CSD
properties.author: Rachel Cole
properties.content: Look at the clock in your classroom. If you were to start a project at 11:00 am and work on it for 2 and a half hours straight, at what time during the day would you finish?

properties.title: Parking Questions: "Wheels of Fortune"
properties.author: Rachel Cole
properties.content:
Count the number of cars in the first row facing the Community School of Davidson. Now, figureÂ  out how many wheels there are in the first row.
(Hint: use multiplication)

What if two of the cars were replaced by motorcycles? How many wheels would there be then?

properties.title: 'The Price is Right' at Ming's
properties.author: Rachel Cole
properties.content: You want to go to Mingâs for lunch, and you have $20. You buy the Basil Chicken for $10.95, but you also want some egg rolls to share with friends. If egg rolls cost $1.25, how many can you buy?

properties.title: Davidson Chocolate Shop Distributions
properties.author: Rachel Cole
properties.content:
If you have three packages of 30 pieces of candy, what are the different ways it could be distributed/divided among:

1. Your Family

2. A group of 5 friends

3. Your class at CSD

properties.title: Shopping List Adventures
properties.author: Rachel Cole
properties.content:
Let's think about a shopping list! You go to the store and want to buy three items:
1 Doughnut ($0.89)
1 French Baquette ($2.99)
1 Boarshead American Cheese packet ($6.49)

If you can only give the cashier dollar bills, use rounding to determine how much money to give the cashier.
What if you could use coins too? How would you pay then?

properties.title: Cereal Dilemma
properties.author: Rachel Cole
properties.content:
Take a trip to the Cereal Aisle of Harris Teeter:

Harris Teeter offers 2 brands of similar cereals: General Mills' Lucky Charms and the Harris Teeter brand, "Magic Stars." Lucky Charms costs $3.95 and Magic Stars costs $2.49. If you have $10.00, how many boxes of each can you buy?

Â

properties.title: Water Fountain
properties.author: Cameron, Lucy, Lea Joe, Boswell, McBryde
properties.content: 6) Water Fountain: If there are 100 total gallons of water stored in the water fountain, and your class drinks 37 gallons in a week, how many gallons of water are left over in the fountain at the end of the week? Solution: 100 â 37 = 63 gallons.

properties.title: Swing Set in the Playground
properties.author: Cameron, Lucy, Lea Joe, Boswell, McBryde
properties.content: 5) Swing Set (in the playground): Joe jumps off the swing a total of 84 times. If he jumps off and lands on his feet 46 times, how many times did Cam jump off and not land on his feet? Solution: 84 â 46 = 38 times.

properties.title: Slide in the Playground
properties.author: Cameron, Lucy, Lea Joe, Boswell, McBryde
properties.content: 4) Slide (in the playground): Lea slides down the slide 47. Cam slides down the slide 33 times. How many times total did Lea and Cam slide down the slide? Solution: 47 + 33 = 80 times.

properties.title: Stop in the name of math
properties.author: ali defrancesch
properties.content: Stop Sign (there is one near the union, we can choose a different location, possibly nearer to the school). Questions: âwhat shape is the stop sign (if they know)? Is it 2-d or 3-d? how many sides does it have? If this shape were to have 3 sides, what shape would it be?â Step 1: What Shape is the stop sign? Step 2: is it 2-d or 3-d? Step 3: How many sides does the stop sign have? BONUS: if the stop sign had two fewer sides, what shape could be made with the remaining sides?

properties.title: Football Sled
properties.author: Cameron, Lucy, Lea Joe, Boswell, McBryde
properties.content: 3) Football Sled: How many dummies (the leather pads) are on this sled? Answer:5. If there are 5 dummies on this sled, and we want a sled with 32 dummies, how many dummies would we need to add? Solution: 32 â 5 = 27 dummies.

properties.title: Time and numbers
properties.author: ali defrancesch
properties.content: Students should stand at the Flagpole outside of Chambers (on the side where Belk hall/other dorms are). Students will be asked to face the Clock on the top of the building. Questions asked: âWhat time is it? In what increments do the numbers increase? What time will it be in 30 min?â Step 1: What time is it? Step 2: What time will it be in 15 minutes? Step 3: what time will it be in 30 minutes? Step 4: in what increments to the numbers increase? Step 5: How many minutes until the next hour?

properties.title: Big Tree
properties.author: Cameron, Lucy, Lea Joe, Boswell, McBryde
properties.content: 2) Big Tree (by the fence at the edge of campus): Suppose a tree loses 527 leaves in the fall, but grows 400 more in the spring, how many leaves total does the tree lose? Solution: 527 â 400 = 127 leaves.

properties.title: Basketball Hoop
properties.author: Cameron, Lucy, Lea Joe, Boswell, McBryde
properties.content: 1) Basketball Hoop: If there are 15 feet between the baseline of a basketball court (the line below the hoop) and the free throw line, and 27 feet between the free throw line and the half-court line, how many feet total are there between the baseline and the half-court line? Solution: 15 + 27 = 42 feet.

properties.title: Sculpture Garden
properties.author: ali defrancesch
properties.content: Activity 6: Inside Davidson College Sculpture garden. Students will observe the sculptures in the garden. Step 1: How many sculptures are 3-D? Step 2: what shapes are evident in some of the sculptures? (rectangle, square, circle, etc.) of these recognizable shapes, how many sides do they have?

properties.title: Group of 10
properties.author: ali defrancesch
properties.content: Davidson Magdalena Abakanowicz Scultpures. How many sculptures are there? How many are the same height (small, medium, large)? Step 1: stand in front of the Abakanowicz sculptures. How many sculputres are there? Step 2: How many are the same height (how many are small? How many are medium? How many are large?) Record these stats, as you will need them for the next step Step 3: walk over to the outdoor classroom, use the chalkboard. Step 4: Make a bar graph with a scale. X-axis label small medium large, y-axis label 1- 10. Create the graph Step 5: how many sculptures are small, how many medium, how many large?

properties.title: Getting Downs with math
properties.author: ali defrancesch
properties.content:
Davidson Richardson Stadium
Students will start in one end zone; then they will be asked a question, âBy how much does each number increase?â object is to have the students count by 10s (the football field is numbered that way) to the 50-yard line (or they can continue to the other end zone)
 
Step 1: Assemble kids in endzone
Step 2: walk to the 10-yard line. Then continue to the next line (5 yrds). How many yards were traveled in all.
Step 3: continue to the 30 yard line. How many yards between the 10 and 20 yard line? How many yards to the 50 yard line?
BONUS: count how many yards long is the foot ball field.

properties.title: Swing into Circumference
properties.author: ali defrancesch
properties.content: Step 1: Notice the swing. It attached to the tree. What is the shape of its enclosure what shape do the bricks make? Step 2: Count how many bricks on the top make up this shape. By counting the number of bricks, you also find out the circumference. (explain what the meaning of the circumference is: it is the distance around the perimeter of the circle).

properties.title: Math & Snacks
properties.author: ali defrancesch
properties.content: Question: You have a total of $8. If you buy $6 worth of bananas and 2 apples, how much did the two apples cost?

properties.title: Dork-ic Columns
properties.author: Hilary Zipperstein
properties.content: Â  Although they are not, assume, for the purposes of this exercise, that the circumferences of the tops and bottoms of the columns are the same. Moreover, assume that the outer columns have half the height of the inner two. Â </p><p>If the inner columns are 25 feet in height and have a diameter of 2.5 feet, what is the total volume of the four columns

properties.title: Connect Four...Minus One
properties.author: Hilary Zipperstein
properties.content: Â  Â Â At this location, you will find three brick planters, like the one seen below, connected by a small brick walkway. Using a measuring tape to assist you, find the total area of the bricks in these three circles, including the rectangular pathways which connect them.Note: This value does not include the plot in the middle of the circles, so take this into consideration when making your calculations.

properties.title: Abstract Volume
properties.author: Hilary Zipperstein
properties.content: Following the conclusion of your hunt for rectangles at the post office, turn your body 180 degrees to find the next activity. Davidson College campus is covered in art of all types, from massive oil canvases to abstract pieces such as this one. What looks wacky at first is actually a series of geometric shapes! How cool! Find the volume of this sculpture using your knowledge of cubic and pyramidal volumes.

properties.title: Find the Most at the Post
properties.author: Hilary Zipperstein
properties.content: Fun Fact: Davidson College has its own zip code! Since zip codes are numbers, and this is math, we thought the Union post office would be perfect place to find some applicable geometry. Looking from Box #6345 to #6311, find as many rectangles as you possibly can. *Hint: be VERY creative here; there will be many more rectangles than you originally conceive.

properties.title: SurfACE Area
properties.author: Hilary Zipperstein
properties.content: Â A standard tennis court is 78 ft in length and 27 ft in width. Calculate the total surface area of all of Davidson College's outdoor tennis courts.

properties.title: Greenway Garden
properties.author: Julia Watkins
properties.content: Â  Â  Look through the fence at the garden.Â  There are 21 total beds in this garden.Â  In October, the gardeners planted lettuce in 7 of these beds, beets in 4 of these beds, and flowers in 10 of these beds.Â  What fraction of the beds contains lettuce?Â  What fraction contains beets?Â  What fraction contains flowers?Â  Make sure you simplify your answers! Â  Â  Answer: 7/21 = 1/3 contain lettuce 4/21 contain beets 10/21 contain flowers Â  Â

properties.title: Tree in Front of Lake Norman Christian School
properties.author: Julia Watkins
properties.content: Â  Â  Stand in front of the big tree to the right of the main school building.Â  Every fall, this tree sheds thousands of leaves.Â  If the average leaf falls from this treeâs branches at the rate of 7 in/sec, how quickly would a leaf fall in in/hr?Â  What about in/ms?Â  Ft/sec?Â  Ft/min? Â  Â  Answer: 7 in/secÂ = 60 sec/1 minÂ = 60 min/1 hr = 7(60)(60) = 25,200 in/hr 7 in/secÂ = .001 sec/1 msÂ = 7(.001) =.007 in/ms 7 in/secÂ = 12 in/1 ftÂ = 7/12 = 0.583 ft/sec 7 in/secÂ = 12 in/1 ftÂ = 7/12 = .583Â = 60 sec/1 min = .583(60) =35 ft/min Â

properties.title: Ben&Jerry's - Vermonster
properties.author: Tyler Jang
properties.content: Â (Without using a calculator) If a Vermonster costs $40.58, how much would 10 Vermonsters cost? How about 100 Vermonsters? 1/10 of a Vermonster? 1/100 of a Vermonster?Â Â Answer: 10 Vermonsters = $405.8; 100 Vermonsters = $4,058; 1/10 Vermonster =Â $4.058;1/100Â Vermonster = $0.4058Â

properties.title: Greenway Bridge - Water in the Stream
properties.author: Tyler Jang
properties.content: Â If the total amount of water in the river under the bridge equals 660,430 gallons, how much is that in quarts?Â Â Answer: 1 quart = 0.25 gallon. Therefore, 660,430 gallons = 2,641,720 quarts.Â

properties.title: Houses
properties.author: Paisley Lewis
properties.content: Â  Look at four of the houses surrounding you.Â  Pretend that two of the houses have two cars and three bicycles each in their driveways.Â  Another house has one car and two bicycles.Â  The final house has three cars, four bicycles, and one tricycle.Â  How many wheels are in the four driveways, combined? Â  Â  Answer: Houses 1 and 2: (2 x 4) + (3 x 2) = 8 + 6 = 14 x 2 = 28 wheels House 3: (1 x 4) + (2 x 2) = 4 + 4 = 8 wheels House 4: (3 x 4) + (4 x 2) + (1 x 3) = 12 + 8 + 3 = 23 wheels Total: 28 + 8 + 23 = 59 wheels Â

properties.title: Baseball Field
properties.author: Paisley Lewis
properties.content: Â  The baseball field that you see in front of you is a square with a base at each of its four corners.Â  If the distance between first base and second base is 45 feet, then what is the area of the field? Now, pretend that you want a large group of students to sit on the baseball field.Â  If each student is allowed 5 square feet of personal space, how many students could fit on the field? Â  Â  Answer: 45 x 45 = 2025 square feet Answer: 2025 / 5 = 405 students Â

properties.title: Davidson Elementary Wall
properties.author: Paisley Lewis
properties.content: Â  Examine the wall on the side of Davidson Elementary.Â  If there are 680 bricks on this wall, and each brick measures 8 x 3 inches, what is the surface area of the entire wall? Â  Â  Answer: Surface area of each brick: (8)(3) inches = 24 in2 24 x 680 = 16,320 in2 is the surface area of the entire wall Â

properties.title: Tennis Courts
properties.content: How many different rectangles are there on one side of a tennis court? What is the difference between a square and rectangle? Are there any squares?

properties.title: Visual Arts Center
properties.content: Describe the relative position of the circles and rectangles on the building's face.

properties.title: Davidson Soda Shop
properties.content: Â  What is the shape of the tiles on the floor? What is the shape of the table? What is the shape of the top of the stools? What are some examples of other shapes in the soda shop?Â

properties.title: Baker Sports Complex
properties.content: Count the number of spheres outside of the building. How many are there? What is the difference between the spheres and the circle on the pavement?

properties.title: Football Field
properties.content: What shape are the lights? Â How many of them are there on one of these?

properties.title: Griffith and Main
Modern Art
Lingel Chapel
properties.content: Â  Â  Â  Â

properties.title: DCPC Steeple
Davidson Lawn Sidewalks
Phi Hall Arch
Chambers Dome
Chambers/belk quad
Angle of Elevation
properties.author: Hilary Zipperstein
properties.content: Although there is too a standard height for a field goal post, this value is not given to you. Instead, stand at the 50 yard line (note that this is sixty yards from the base of the field goal) and use the angle of elevation to find the height of the post.To do this, you will need:-One paper towel roll-Six-inch string-One protractorFirst, attach the string to any point along the rim of the paper towel roll (tape works well). Feed a half-inch of the string inside the roll and tape it down, so that the string hangs out of the bottom of the paper towel's opening. With a partner, one person should, standing at the fifty yard line, look through the paper towel roll up to the top of the goal post. While the first person holds still, the second person should take a standard 180 degree protractor and hold it along the bottom of the paper towel roll so that the "0" degree mark aligns with the opening of the roll. The string will hang down, aligning with a value on the protractor thus creating an obtuse angle with the bottom edge of the elevated protractor as the angle's base. This angle's supplementary angle will serve as your angle of elevation.Â

properties.title: Mathletics
properties.author: Hilary Zipperstein
properties.content: The circumference of a perfect circle is very easy to find. On the contrary, the circumference of largely imperfect circle, such as the Davidson College track, is a bit more difficult. The width of a standard college football field is 53.5 yd and the length of a football field is, for the most part, common knowledge. Using these two values, calculate the approximate circumference of the track in feet.Â

properties.title: Gazebo
properties.author: Tom Droney
properties.content: Â  You want to figure out how much water can be held in the round trash can. Â What is the volume of the cylinder when the base circle has a diameter of 2ft? Figuring out that was too easy, so now you want Â to figure out how much water could fit into the octagonalÂ prismÂ that makes up the majority of the gazebo. What is the area of the base of the gazebo? (Hint: It's an octagon.) What is the volume of the gazebo between the floor and the ceiling? (Ignore the cone-shaped roof.) What if the gazebo was 3.7 times larger? What would the volume be for this new gazebo? Â  Â

properties.title: Lakeside Dock
properties.author: Tom Droney
properties.content: Â You want to make a dock that is 6ft wide and 20ft long from the shore. For the dock to be stable, you need a pair (two) of support boards connected to the dock every 5ft. The water gets 4ins deeper each foot into the water. Â The support boards must go 1ft into the ground to provide stability.How many support boards will you need for the dock to be stable? (Hint: The shore starts at 0ft.)How deep will the water be at the end of the dock?How long will each of the pairs of support boards need to be? (Remember that the water gets deeper the further out you go, and that the boards need to be Â 1ft into the ground.)(Hint: A diagram will be helpful when trying to solve this problem. In order to get you started on the right track a diagram has been provided below. You should NOT rely on this diagram in order to answer the questions.)Â Â

properties.title: Boat rack
properties.author: Tom Droney
properties.content: The community wants to put in additional boat racks with the same measurements as the ones already there. Unfortunately, the original designs for the boat racks have been lost, and your group is tasked with figuring out the details for this project. What are the surface area and volumes of the boat racks?Â (Hint: Surface Area:Â Â Rectangular prism- 2 (L x W) +2 (H x W) +2 (L x H), Volume- (L x W x H)) If you were given 500 cubic ft of wood, how many boat racks could you build? (Hint: You may have leftover wood.) 1 cubic foot of wood costs $5.00. How much would it cost to build a boat rack that is 2.5 times the size of the ones that are already there? Â

properties.title: Trail bench
properties.author: Tom Droney
properties.content: As a class project, you and your classmates want to paint one of the benches on the trail. The bench is made out of six total boards (ignore the little bottom boards). Find the dimensions of the boards.Â (Hint: Three of the boards, labeled âAâ are the same dimensions. The other three, labeled âBâ are of the same dimensions. (One of the âBâ boards is cut in half to make the back supports of the bench.)) What is the total surface area of the bench? (Hint: Surface Area:Â Â Rectangular prism- 2 (L x W) +2 (H x W) +2 (L x H)) How much paint are you going to need to paint one bench if one gallon of paint covers approximately 350 sq ft? If a gallon of paint costs $10,how much would it cost Â to paint five benches?

properties.title: White Oak Tree
properties.author: Tom Droney
properties.content: You and your classmates want to figure out the distance from the top of the tree to the end of the shadow. You estimate that the tree is 50ft tall and it is casting a shadow that is 80ft long. (Hint: The Pythagorean Theorem may be useful.)A few minutes later, you see a bird sitting 30ft up in the tree. Â The approximate length from the top of the bird's head to the top of the tree's shadow is 70ft. Â What is the approximate length of the shadow?Â (Hint: A diagram may be helpful.)Â Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Â

properties.title: Trail map
properties.author: Tom Droney
properties.content: Â Note: for this location, either the map at the entrance of the trail or the one out on the sidewalk will be fine.Â You and your classmates are curious to know how far each Geotagged Math Map point is from one another. Measure the length of the trail between the following locations:The entrance to the trail and the benchThe bench and the treeThe tree and the boat launch.The boat launch and where the âbuilding a dockâ question wasThe dock and the gazeboUsing these distances, find the total distance you traveled during this activity. Â (Hint: you went there AND back!)How long did you travel on the trail?What was your approximate average speed? (Hint: use the distance you traveled and divide it by the time it took you to travel.)Â Say the community wanted to cover the first 100 yards of the trail with gravel 3 inches thick. Assume the trail is 4 feet wide.-How much gravel would be required?Â -If each truck contains 80 square feet of gravel, how many truckloads would be required?Â Â

properties.title: Boat Rack Fractions
properties.author: Matt Zarth
properties.content: Fractions Place fractional values in lowest terms. 1. Pick a boat rack and decide what fraction of the rack is filled with boats. 2. Now using all of the boat racks, find the fraction of the racks that are filled with boats. 3. There are boats of different colors in the boat racks. Find the fraction of the boats that are each color. 4. If a person was to walk along the trail and try to take a boat from a rack at random, what is the probability that they would pick a rack without a boat? What about a yellow boat? 5. What would be the probability of selecting a rack with either a blue or yellow boat? Printable Worksheet Answer Key (This is subject to change based on boats in the rack at the time of the activity. We have put together a key based on the boats that were in the racks as of December 4, 2012.) Â  Â

properties.title: Finding Geometric Objects
properties.author: Matt Zarth
properties.content: Our world is filled with shapes and geometric objects. From halfway between the pit and the trash cans outside the Gazebo, find as many geometric objects (triangles, rectangles, etc.) as you can. Also, attempt to determine the geometric objects desrcibed below and then find objects along the trail that fit the description.1. An object containing four corners and 4 right angles. The top of the object is the same length as the bottom and the left side is the same length as the right.2. A shape that is 2-dimensional and the distance from the center to the edge is the same at all points on the edge.3. A 3-dimensional object that contains circles on either end. It is able to roll down hills and is plentiful in forests.4.Â  A shape that comes to sharp points and that has three sides.5. An object with the ability to roll and the center is the same distance from all of its sides.Printable WorksheetAnswer Key

properties.title: The Gazebo
properties.author: Matt Zarth
properties.content: 1. Draw the Shape of the Gazebo from an overhead view. Â  2. Find as many shapes as you can in positive space. Â  3. Find as many shapes as you can in negative space. Â  4. Measure the interior angles of the gazebo with your protractor. Â  5. Add all the angles that you measured with your protractor together in order to find the sum of the interior angles. Â  6. Find the lines of symmetry of the Gazebo from an overhead perspective using the drawing from question one. Â  7. Find the lines of symmetry of the Gazebo when viewing from the ramp. Â  Printable Worksheet. Â  Answer Key. Â

properties.title: The Chain Link Fence
properties.author: Matt Zarth
properties.content: In each section of the fence there are 799 individual squares. How many squares would there be if you added two sections of fence together? How many squares would be in a section of fence if you took out 532 squares? How many squares would be in a section of fence if you added 239 squares? Printable worksheet. Answer key.
